Website Coding Bascis

  • HTML Tags
  • Floats
  • Flexbox
  • Grid

HTML Tags

<b> and <strong>

Both of these tags will make text look bold. The <strong> tag also describes higher text importance than the first. Also, according to the HTML 5 specification, the <b> tag should only be used as a LAST resort, when no other tag is more appropriate.

HTML:

<b>bold text</b>

Result:

bold text

<i> and <em>

Both tags will make text look italic. The <em> tag also describes a higher emphasis than the first. Also, according to the HTML 5 specification, the <i> tag should be only used as a LAST resort when no other tag is more appropriate.

HTML:

<i>italic text</i>

Result:

italic text

<span>

This tag is used to group inline elements on the page. The tag itself provides no visual change, but you can use it as a hook to gain access to it with CSS or JS. For example if you want to change a part of a text with different style or layout, you will wrap the desired text in this tag, add some class and target it with CSS.

HTML:

<span>sample text</span>

Result:

sample text

<em>

This is tag used to emphasize parts of a text. Makes a text, or text within a text to stand out a bit. You can also use it as a hook for CSS and JS, as the span tag, but have it be more semantic for particular cases.

HTML:

<em>sample text</em>

Result:

sample text

<code>

This tag is used to define a piece of computer code. You can use it to wrap some of your favorite snippet that you want to post on your site. Like a lot of other tags, it's mostly for writing semantic code. But you can target this particular tag with JS and CSS to make it highlighted like a proper editor and make it look really nice and pretty.

HTML:

<code>sample text</code>

Result:

sample text

<samp>

This tag is used to wrap the output of the computer program. So, for example, if you have a little console web application within your site, you can use this tag to wrap your console command returns. This will make it semantic, and you can use it as a hook to style it or to access it with JS.

HTML:

<samp>sample text</samp>

Result:

sample text

<kbd>

This tag is used to define keyboard input. For example, if you have a little application that requires you to enter something, and there isn't another more semantic tag, you can use this one. Like all others, it can be used as a hook for CSS styling or JS logic.

HTML:

<kbd>sample text</kbd>

Result:

sample text

<var>

This tag is used to define a variable. You might use it as a hook and style specific piece of text which is your variables within a text or stands alone text.

HTML:

<var>sample text</var>

Result:

sample text

<br>

This tag inserts a single line break. This line serves as the 'enter' key for the webpage, like in a word document. Also, this is an empty self-closing tag which means that it has no need for a closing tag.

HTML:

<br /> Text

Result:


Text

<hr>

This element is used to separate content or define a change in the HTML page. This tag puts a full line across the whole page within the parent box.

HTML:

<hr /> Text

Result:

Text

<p>

This is the paragraph tag, widely used for containing a block of text. This paragraph tags come some default left margin from the user agent CSS.

HTML:

<p>Text</p>

Result:

Text

<ins>

This tag is to be used to notify users that some new text has been inserted. By default, the browsers display an underline to make the text stand out. As far as I have seen, this reason this the tag is often not seen compared to its counterpart <del>.

HTML:

<ins>Text<ins>

Result:

Text

<s>

This tag is similar to the <del> tag, The difference is that text is not relevant anymore, yet not it's not deleted. This tag is usually used by online shops to highlight a price discount.

HTML:

Price: <s>£199</s>

Result:

Price: £199

<del>

This tag is to be used on text that is deleted but still kept as a reference. This tag is usually used in blogs websites where the incorrect text is marked, but not deleted.

HTML:

It was my <del>worst</del> idea.

Result:

It was my worst best idea.

<mark>

This tag is to be used to define and highlight parts of your text in a way a marker would on a piece of paper.

HTML:

<mark>Text</mark>

Result:

Text

<sup>

This tag defines superscript text. Superscript text appears half a character above the normal line and is rendered in a smaller font.

HTML:

5<sup>th<sup/>

Result:

5th

<sub>

This tag defines subscript text. Subscript text appears half a character below the normal line and is rendered in a smaller font.

HTML:

H <sub>2<sub/>O

Result:

H2O

<cite>

This tag is used to define text that you would want to reference. In HTML5 this should refer to the text itself and not the author.

HTML:

<cite>Text</cite>

Result:

Text

<abbr>

This is the new acronym tag and it's used for abbreviations. Basically, if you have a shortened term like 'WHO' you can have this term in <abbr> tag, and when the user hovers over the term he will get a pop-up with full text.

HTML:

<abbr class="World Health Organization">Text</abbr>

Result:

WHO

<dfn>

This tag is used to explain new terminologies. They call it the defining instance of a new term. So if you are describing something complicated like a hedge fund you would use this tag. This will be used by screen readers, most browsers would not do anything to the text itself, but some would make the text italic.

HTML:

<dfn title="Text">Text</dfn>

Result:

Text

<q>

This tag is used for short quotation and the browser usually insert quotation marks around the quote.

HTML:

<q>Text</q>

Result:

Don't cry because it's over, smile because it happened. – Dr. Seuss

<small>

This tag is used to define small text or any side comment that you want to deemphasize. It is usually used within the footer of the site for the copyright info as by default as it's smaller.

HTML:

<small>small text</small>

Result:

small text

<backquote>

This tag is used to define and reference a full paragraph quote. This tag is very similar to the <q> tag, but the <q> is for short one or two sentences quotes.

HTML:

<backquote>

<p>

You've gotta dance like there's nobody <br>
watching, Love like you'll never be hurt, Sing like <br>
there's nobody listening, And live like it's heaven <br>
on earth. – William W. Purkey

</p>

</backquote>

Result:

You've gotta dance like there's nobody
watching, Love like you'll never be hurt, Sing like
there's nobody listening, And live like it's heaven
on earth. – William W. Purkey

<address>

This is the tag used for addresses, it's pretty much self-explanatory. just use it in combination with other tags like </br>, </div> with a indent margin class to properly display your address.

HTML:

<address>

Business Name <br>
The Parkside Building <br>
5 Cardigan St <br>
Birmingham <br>
B4 7BD <br>

<address>

Result:

Business Name
The Parkside Building
5 Cardigan St
Birmingham
B4 7BD

Floats

Example 1

In this first example, we have a div within div, a box, and a wrap. The box has been styled with fixed with and height, plus a small margin and the wrap has a red border. This is the standard behavior of a div within a div, nothing has been floated here.

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Example 2

This is our first proper example of floating an element. As you can see the div has been floated to the right, and it has moved all the way to the top right. The problem with floating objects is that their parent loses its height. As you can see, the parent wrap no has 0 height.

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Example 3

In this example, we have text wrapped in P-tag and div, both within a single div. This is the standard behavior of the objects. No floats have been applied here.

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Neque natus, in illum, quas eaque optio ducimus laudantium vitae cumque rerum deserunt rem adipisci hic quidem debitis eius tenetur enim necessitatibus?

Example 4

This is a continuation from the previous example. Let us say you want to have a picture within the text and you want the text to wrap around it. Well, you can use a float. No clearfix has been applied, the parent height isn't 0, what happened? Well, the parent box wrapping itself around the text.

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Neque natus, in illum, quas eaque optio ducimus laudantium vitae cumque rerum deserunt rem adipisci hic quidem debitis eius tenetur enim necessitatibus?

Example 5

Look What happens if we have the same example, but the text tag is outside of the red div wrap that we used previously. The height has collapsed to 0. But in many cases, we don't want this to happen.

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Neque natus, in illum, quas eaque optio ducimus laudantium vitae cumque rerum deserunt rem adipisci hic quidem debitis eius tenetur enim necessitatibus?

Example 6

Here is the solution to the previous problem, the clear fix function which fixes the collapsed height of the red wrapper div. This is very useful because if you don't clearfix your floats, most times your layout will get messed up.

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Neque natus, in illum, quas eaque optio ducimus laudantium vitae cumque rerum deserunt rem adipisci hic quidem debitis eius tenetur enim necessitatibus?

Example 1

For reference, in our first example, you can see the standard look of few divs within a parent div. Just CSS styles have been applied.

Box-1

Box-3

Example 2

In this first example are not only setting the parent to display flex. We are also, setting the flex-direction to a column with reversed order. You can also use this property without the reverse function, which is how it would usually be used.

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Box-1
Box-2
Box-3

Example 3

This what happens to the first example once you apply a display flex property. As you can see, by default the direction is changed to the column and the boxes no longer stretch to the full width of the page.

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Box-1
Box-2
Box-3

Example 4

In this example, we can see what happens when we display as flex, then apply flex direction of row and reverse the display direction.

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Box-1
Box-2
Box-3

Example 5

In this example, we are again displaying the parent as flex, but this time we have set each box to have 40% width. As you can see, each box does not have 40% with. What happens here is that the box simply stretches out as much as possible, but doesn't break the box model to make each box width 40%.

Result:

Box-1
Box-2
Box-3

Example 6

There is a property of flex that allows you to wrap each item to the next line. It's called flex-wrap. We have the same code as the previous example, but here we have applied the flex-wrap property to the parent which cases the boxes to wrap once they run out of space. As you can see each box is has a 40% width.

Result:

Box-1
Box-2
Box-3

Example 7

This is the justify property. It can move the boxes to the start, center, and end of the parent box. Don't forget that if you change the flow of flex using the flex-direction property, you can to use the align-items property to have the same effect.

Result:

These are the two extra properties for justifying items, space-between, and space-around. Very useful. You can also use them with other flex align properties.

Example 9

In this example, we have used the align-items property to align all the boxes to some spot vertically. You can notice that here we have the default flex direction, which is a column. So, align-items aligns the boxes to the top, middle or bottom. The default property is stretch which stretches the box to 100% width. Please note that we have applied static height to the parent box.

Example 10

Here we have used a less commonly used property align-self to one of the boxes for each example. You can use this property to individually align boxes to the top, middle or bottom.

Example 11

In this example, I am showcasing very interesting property, flex-grow. You can use this property to dynamically assign more space to one object over another. There is also the flex-shrink property which does exactly the opposite. This property is very useful when you have objects that must be smaller or bigger than the rest. The best use for this is in the responsive design, where the pages get smaller all the boxes will keep the ratios, which is really sweet!

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Box-1
Box-2
Box-3

Example 12

In this final example, we are covering the shorthand flex property. In this property, you can assign flex-grow, flex-shrink and flex-basis. We have already covered the first two, so least cover the last. Flex-basis is the ideal width you want for your box. For example, you can set 20% or 100px etc, and the browser will try to match this requirement, but if they're too many boxes then the layout will not get broken, the box will simply have a smaller width. This is amazing!

HTML + CSS:

Result:

Box-1
Box-2
Box-3
